channel.title: Working with Java
channel.description: I've been researching some jobs that Jagex offers and I've noticed there are many separate teams they have for RS (obviously) and from what I read, you aren't required to have any type of collegical education in the career you choose. For example: Jagex's Game Engine/Core Technologies Developer requires that you are [i]very[/i] proficient at using Java, C++ or C#, which means you must have extreme knowledge of at least one of those languages. I know the most professional way to acquire a great Java knowledge and understanding is attending some type of university that offers that type of class for your desired language. My question being, is it really worth it to get a college education for the language (which is what I would like to do) or would reading it out of a book be more efficient?

item.title: Working with Java
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

[quote=“parkview, post:21, topic:437744”][quote author=t4 link=topic=540445.msg3959293#msg3959293 date=1333122503]

What about COBOL?

seems useless
[/quote]

Useless ? Wrong. The answer we were looking for was VERY useful. (Mainframes are run by huge companies, such as banks, IBM, oil companies etc.)[/quote]
People that associate with certain material think other methods are null and void; it is just instinct.

Read full topic

item.title: Working with Java
item.dc:creator: @Hash1 Hash1
item.description:
@Hash1 wrote:

Rodgerwilco:

Don’t focus on jagex… look into other gaming companies. You would probably find a more enjoyable career at blizzard for example. As stated, I would rather take experienced programmers based on their personality and previous work. It goes that way for any job…

Why would he have a more enjoyable career at Blizzard than at Jagex?

Read full topic

item.title: Working with Java
item.dc:creator: @parkview parkview
item.description:
@parkview wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:17, topic:437744”][quote author=_s link=topic=540445.msg3959468#msg3959468 date=1333139337]

What about COBOL?

seems useless
[/quote]haha, COBOL knowledge is actually in huge demand. you wouldn’t believe how many legacy infrastructures and mainframes use it.

that went though my mind, but i dismissed it thinking people who have upgraded by now[/quote]

COBOL goes back in the 1950’s. The IBM mainframe uses JCL and COBOL/FORTRAN. (and other veriouse old ass languages.) I’m taking a cobol programming class in college here in Canada, and COBOL/JCL programmers are VERY VERY high in demand. Converting from COBOL mainframes to java or a modern language would cost WAYY to much money for the big companies. COBOL is an extremely useful language, it may be tediouse to code, but learning it is very useful as it is used a lot in the job industry. Legacy systems are recruiting cobol programmers, and paying them very well ! XD (Fresh legacy, Montreal)

PS. sorry for digging this topic :S lol

Read full topic

that went though my mind, but i dismissed it thinking people who have upgraded by now[/quote]#1 rule is to remember that they don’t fix what isn’t broken, and those mainframes have lasted for years, and will last for years to come. it’s cheaper for them to bring in maintainers than to upgrade the things.

[quote=“t4, post:11, topic:437744”]i found out my uni has courses in lisp/haskell/scala (aka functional programming 101 lol), i shall be taking these![/quote]i don’t like how scala is thrown in there, but sure.

[/quote]
We had something similar called programming languages, we had a soup bowl rather than course, we did from Verilog,assembly X86 , Lisp, Ruby, haskell, Python, and Erlang. It was a Mess[/quote]wow, that must have been hard going. also, Erlang? jeez, you don’t see that often in an educational setting.

item.title: Working with Java
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“imsuperman05, post:5, topic:437744”]You go to college for the degree and use that to represent your experience. At least that’s the way I see it.[/quote]any manager/recruiter worth his salt should realise that a comp sci degree doesn’t entail experience at anything other than the ability to take an exam, hand in homework and read books. more specific software engineering degrees will be better, but i can’t imagine they’d be too much better. creating a good portfolio will only ever benefit your cause and will indicate a lot about you.

[quote=“SETO, post:8, topic:437744”][quote author=t4 link=topic=540445.msg3958102#msg3958102 date=1332973818]
languages, especially those derived from C (which is everything you’ve mentioned) are pretty much syntactically the same. real programming skill comes from a rich background of understanding of algorithms, design, etc which is all more or less generic to any language.
[/quote]
In reality you don’t have to be expert in every programming lang, i started with C,and after that learning other languages are easy, in reality learning any programing language is very easy, if you are a good problem solver and good with algorithms and basic understanding of at least one language[/quote]i think the more realistic reality is that picking up other imperative languages is made much easier by already knowing one imperative language however an undergraduate’s typical struggles with Prolog and Scheme/Haskell are usually evidence against picking up new paradigms being made much easier, and a lot of companies are now opting for things like Scala and Erlang. Twitter notably ditched Ruby with RoR for Scala and many companies use Erlang internally because of it’s effectively unparalleled concurrency features.

[quote=“Trebel, post:9, topic:437744”]going to college would be the best.[/quote]for some yes, but i think it’s completely dependent upon the person in question

Read full topic

item.title: Working with Java
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

t4:

languages, especially those derived from C (which is everything you’ve mentioned) are pretty much syntactically the same. real programming skill comes from a rich background of understanding of algorithms, design, etc which is all more or less generic to any language.

In reality you don’t have to be expert in every programming lang, i started with C,and after that learning other languages are easy, in reality learning any programing language is very easy, if you are a good problem solver and good with algorithms and basic understanding of at least one language

Read full topic

item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

Don’t focus on jagex… look into other gaming companies. You would probably find a more enjoyable career at blizzard for example. As stated, I would rather take experienced programmers based on their personality and previous work. It goes that way for any job…

Read full topic

item.title: Working with Java
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

a request of proficiency with a language doesn’t mean that you need to fully understand the language’s fundamental workings; it’s more of a request for working experience and a broad scope of knowledge and application with said language ie. networking and concurrency. although fundamental knowledge and implementation understanding is useful to know, i wouldn’t say that it’s a prerequisite since most software engineering jobs stray away from working at that level, so while a content developer would probably never need to know anything too low-level, it would be expected of a core engine developer to have knowledge of lower-level topics.

it depends really on what you want to end up doing, but experience is one of the most important things. a self-taught hobbyist with lots of projects, lots of varied presented works and experience working on popular (open-source) projects will have a very good chance of getting a job in comparison to a by-the-book graduate with no real experience, future plans or portfolio.

Read full topic

item.title: Working with Java
item.dc:creator: @Native1 Native^
item.description:
@Native1 wrote:

Not for the language itself, but in order to fully understand any language you’ll have to know the inner workings like how the vm interprets the bytecode. and other concepts like networking and the inner workings of those concepts.

you can learn that yourself, but it’s always better to have a teacher who can explain it clearly to you.

Read full topic

For example: Jagex’s Game Engine/Core Technologies Developer requires that you are very proficient at using Java, C++ or C#, which means you must have extreme knowledge of at least one of those languages. I know the most professional way to acquire a great Java knowledge and understanding is attending some type of university that offers that type of class for your desired language. My question being, is it really worth it to get a college education for the language (which is what I would like to do) or would reading it out of a book be more efficient?
